Step.name: Indicators of Neglect
Step.html: Inadequate physical care both of the person and the environment.

Step.name: Indicators of Neglect
Step.html: Person's physical condition/appearance is poor e.g. pressure ulcers, soiled or wet clothing, malnourished or dehydrated.

Step.name: Indicators of Neglect
Step.html: Person has inadequate food, clothing, heating, lighting and/or shelter.

Step.name: Pressure Ulcers
Step.html: Through neglect, pressure ulcers can develop very quickly and without appropriate intervention they can become very serious. Any pressure ulcer can be painful and cause patient suffering but severe pressure ulcers can destroy the muscle or bone and in extreme cases they can cause infection and become life threatening.

Step.name: Self Neglect
Step.html: Although self neglect is not included in the 'No Secrets' definition of abuse, in such cases this policy will apply where there is deemed to be significant risk to life e.g. where a vulnerable person who has capacity stops caring for themselves and refuses any support or services.

Step.name: Neglect
Step.html:
Neglect is the withholding deliberately or unintentionally of help or support necessary to carry out daily living tasks. This could include ignoring medical and physical care needs, social or educational support. This could also include the withholding of medication, nutrition and heating.

It is often hard to determine the point at which a person starts to become neglected. For this reason it is all the more important that any aspects of poor care and treatment are challenged at the earliest opportunity rather than allowing the person concerned to suffer harm through their continuation.
